bookmarks.text:
This is the best AI coding setup ever:

Codex on the left, Claude Code on the right

1. Start building with Claude Code in plan mode
2. Copy and paste every plan into Codex. Validate the plan. If they have any critical feedback, give it back to CC
3. Any time CC messes up, go back to Codex and have it fix the issue
4. Every change either agent makes, ask the other agent to review it
5. Primarily use whichever agent that is the last one to clean up the other's mess

Not only will you produce apps 10x faster, you'll have fun just feeling like you're managing a team of engineers

Trust me, the results are worth the price you pay

Good if you run make Claude's and don't have time to be in front of the computer.

- ãŸã ç¾çŠ¶ã®ãƒˆãƒ©ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ¼ãƒãƒ¼ã¯æ‰±ãˆã‚‹æ–‡è„ˆã®é•·ã•ã«é™ç•ŒãŒã‚ã‚‹ã€‚ã‚³ãƒ³ãƒ†ã‚­ã‚¹ãƒˆåˆ¶ç´„ã‚’è¶…ãˆã‚‹ä»•çµ„ã¿ï¼ˆé‡ã¿æ›´æ–°ãªã©ï¼‰ãŒã§ãã‚Œã°ã€ãƒ‡ãƒŸã‚¹ã®åŸºæº–ã‚’æº€ãŸã›ã‚‹ã‹ã‚‚ã—ã‚Œãªã„

I can't believe that the once richest man on earth just bet his entire empire on ONE company.

And he has 9 days to pull it off.

SoftBank is scrambling to deliver $22.5 billion to OpenAI by December 31st.

To get there, CEO Masayoshi Son sold his ENTIRE stake in the best-performing AI stock on the planet.

Then sold billions more in other holdings.

Cut staff. Froze dealmaking. Borrowed against everything he owns.

This is the biggest all-in bet in the past few years.

And it might be the most reckless financial engineering since 2008.

Here's what's actually happening:

SoftBank promised OpenAI $40 billion back in April when the company was valued at $300 billion.

The deal had conditions. OpenAI had to convert to a for-profit structure by year-end.

They did that in October.

Now the clock is ticking. $22.5 billion must arrive in 9 days or the deal breaks.

Son already delivered $17.5 billion earlier this year.

Getting the rest is proving harder than anyone expected.

The moves Son made to raise the cash are absolutely wild:

He dumped SoftBank's entire $5.8 billion position in Nvidia.

Not trimmed. Not reduced. LIQUIDATED.

The same Nvidia that's been printing money for AI investors all year.

He sold $4.8 billion worth of T-Mobile shares.

Slashed staff across the company.

And the Vision Fund that used to write checks for everything? Dead.

Any deal over $50 million now requires Son's personal approval.

Investment managers who used to hunt for the next big thing are now working full-time on the OpenAI transaction.

But it still wasn't enough cash...

So Son went to the debt markets.

He expanded SoftBank's margin loan capacity by $6.5 billion, bringing total undrawn capacity to $11.5 billion.

All of it backed by Arm Holdings stock.

If Arm's stock drops, those loans get called. SoftBank faces margin calls. The whole thing unravels.

And the risk gets crazier.

OpenAI's valuation has tripled since April.

Started at $300 billion. Now heading toward $900 billion according to sources.

Amazon is reportedly joining the next round.

On paper, SoftBank's investment looks brilliant. A 3X return in 8 months.

But here's the thing:

OpenAI is hemorrhaging cash at a rate that makes Uber's losses look responsible.

The company generates $13 billion in annual revenue.

Impressive... right?

But they're literally projected to LOSE $74 billion by 2028.

Not break even with losses. Not approach profitability.

$74 billion in the red.

Their revenue is growing. Their losses are growing faster.

Because AI compute costs don't scale down. They scale UP.

Every new ChatGPT user costs OpenAI money. 
Every API call burns cash. 
Every model training run requires millions in compute.

Sam Altman told employees OpenAI is now in "code red" mode.

Pausing all other product launches to focus entirely on beating Google's Gemini.

That's the language of desperation.

And Altman's long-term vision is even more expensive.

He wants to build 30 gigawatts of AI compute capacity.

Cost: $1.4 TRILLION.

For context, that's larger than Mexico's entire GDP.

He wants to add 1 gigawat every single week.

Each gigawatt costs over $40 billion.

The math doesn't work. The business model doesn't work. The capital requirements are impossible.

But Son is betting everything anyway.

Why would he do this?

Because if it works, he owns the future.

If OpenAI becomes the infrastructure layer for the next 20 years of computing, that $22.5 billion turns into trillions.

SoftBank becomes the kingmaker of AI. Son becomes the most powerful investor in history.

But if it fails?

SoftBank vaporizes.

The Nvidia stake is gone. Can't get it back.

The T-Mobile shares are gone.

The margin loans against Arm come due.

Son has systematically dismantled his portfolio to concentrate everything into one bet.

This is the opposite of diversification.

This is the opposite of prudent risk management.

This is a founder going all-in on a vision that everyone else thinks is insane.

And he might be right.

Other investors see it too. That's why OpenAI's valuation tripled in 8 months.

BlackRock, Fidelity, and JP Morgan are all writing massive checks to private AI companies.

Databricks just raised $4 billion at a $134 billion valuation.

The entire market is betting that AI infrastructure will define the next decade.

But the difference?

They're diversifying. Spreading risk. Building portfolios.

Son put everything on one company.

The deadline is December 31st.

In 9 days, we'll know if SoftBank pulled it off.

If they deliver the $22.5 billion on time, the bet stays alive.

If they miss the deadline, the deal could collapse. The terms could change. Competitors could swoop in.

And Son will have sold the farm for nothing.

This is either:

The greatest venture bet in history.

Or the most reckless financial move since Lehman Brothers.

There's no middle ground.

Masayoshi Son doesn't do middle ground.

He bet big on Alibaba in 2000 and turned $20 million into $60 billion.

He bet big on WeWork and lost $14 billion.

Now he's betting bigger than ever.

$22.5 billion. 9 days. Everything on the line.

What would you do?

Kenn Ejima
@kenn

AI stops assisting and starts working by 2026.

A senior executive at Microsoft says the next phase of artificial intelligence wonâ€™t just help humans do tasks, it will do the tasks itself. According to the study and executive commentary, AI is moving rapidly from chatbots and copilots to autonomous systems that can plan, decide, and execute real work across industries.

> In next 6 months, AI still needs humans, but it stops being helpless.
> In next 6 years, AI becomes a digital worker, not a tool.

By around 2026, AI is expected to independently handle complex workflows in areas like finance, logistics, operations, and customer support. Instead of waiting for prompts, these systems will monitor situations, take action, and coordinate multiple steps with minimal human input.

you can use skills to orchestrate subagents for complex workflows, which is a great way to optimize context since each subagent gets its own. been testing this today and it works really well. you could even wrap the entire skill in a subagent that invokes it to save more session context, though that might reduce visibility into what's happening (haven't tested this). weirdly enough, i was able to package the subagents within the skill itself in a {skill}/agents/ folder, which is not documented anywhere, but it seems to work pretty well

top_replies.author: heyJordanParker
top_replies.text:
yes but for fundamental behaviors you'd want a subagent or command, no need for a skill

you're not getting anything from progressive disclosure if it's the main task; worse, you can lose context because it's optional

I usually combine them â€“ having a skill so CC can auto-run it

top_replies.author: alxfazio
top_replies.text: you are partially right, but the fact that i can store the subagents and the outputs they generate directly in the skill is quite nice and useful. i haven't worked with subagents that use skills, mainly because i don't like subagents much, especially since until recently they

top_replies.text: cc could use agent prompt under skill folder, the only cons i see is such agent would be triggered with general task agent, which is default to sonnet, can't force it to use opus.

Note that our 90% prediction intervals are quite wide, spanning a factor of 2x longer or shorter than our central estimate.

Also, ECI underestimated previous Claude models on Time Horizons by 30% on average. If we account for that, we predict Opus 4.5 will get 3.8 hours.

You can now delegate tasks to Claude Code directly from Slack.

Simply tag @.Claude in a channel or thread. Coding tasks will automatically be routed to Claude Code and start up a new session on the web.

bookmarks.text:
In the end LLM chats (AI Search) will move to an ad based system as it is the most sustainable business model at scale.

There will be less ads but they will be much more expensive (valuable) as the intent is higher than in anything else.

My bet is that once they get enough infra/compute $GOOGL will force the industry in that direction with free Gemini. $GOOGL has the edge in that arena as they have the ad muscle as well as relationships with advertisers.

top_replies.author: zazul_ai
top_replies.text: Been thinking about this too. Agree ads will supplement LLM economics, but LLMs will never replicate the margin profile of search. Chat inference is fundamentally heavier than keyword search. You can make it cheap enough to subsidize part of the product (like a â€œGemini Basicâ€),

I tested Anthropic's new AI interviewer 

Feeling listened to + getting adaptive and compelling Qs makes a huge difference vs. a survey - I genuinely enjoyed it (and gave much better answers!)

This has to be the future of market research, customer feedback, etc.

top_replies.author: koylanai
top_replies.text: We have been using an Interviewer agent system in production for expert creation. I shared our architecture and learnings here. Happy to give you access.

top_replies.author: _maxdshaw
top_replies.text: 100%. This is one of the most effective ways to have conversations with your employees at scale. Whether it's about an offsite, what they are blocked, what process sucks or what they would change in the product. Listening to your employees doesn't have to take a lot of time!

OpenAIâ€™s new â€œGarlicâ€ model delivers major pretraining breakthroughs, letting the company pack big-model knowledge into much smaller architectures that still outperform Googleâ€™s Gemini 3 and Anthropic Opus 4.5 in internal coding and reasoning tests.

Garlic fixes structural issues from earlier models like GPT-4.5 and could launch as GPT-5.2/5.5 early next year, marking OpenAIâ€™s attempt to regain momentum after Altmanâ€™s â€œcode red.â€ The model isnâ€™t finished yet - but if evaluations translate to real-world performance, it signals that scaling efficiency isnâ€™t plateauing after all.

bookmarks.text:
november has been absolutely unhinged

nov 12: openai drops gpt-5.1, says it's "warmer and more conversational"

nov 17: xai releases grok 4.1, claims #1 on every leaderboard, 65% fewer hallucinations

nov 18: google launches gemini 3, first model to ever hit 1501 elo, "less prompting needed"

nov 24: anthropic releases opus 4.5, says it "handles ambiguity the way a senior engineer would"

brother i AM a senior engineer. that's literally my job title. they put it in the press release.

four companies mass dropped frontier models in 12 days like they're beefing

each one claiming to be smarter than the last

meanwhile i mass dropped four coffee cups this week and called it a personality

they're fighting for #1 and i'm fighting to remember my slack password

anthropic really said "infinite chat" like i needed MORE time to realize i'm being replaced

the gap isn't closing anymore

the gap graduated, got a job, and is now training its replacement

we are so unbelievably cooked

images.alt: four frontier models in twelve days. i mass dropped four mugs. we are not the same.

Chinaâ€™s electricity consumption has grown by more than: 1 India in 4 years; 1 EU in 6 years; 1 U.S. in 11 years.

Electricity will become the biggest bottleneck in the near future, even more so than chips. And China is *far ahead* of Europe and the USA in *this* electricity production race.

top_replies.text: should be covering the desert in solar panels

top_replies.author: laksh_officiall
top_replies.text: This really puts things in perspective  chips matter, but without massive reliable electricity, none of the AI or industrial growth is even possible. China saw this early and scaled faster than anyone else.

top_replies.author: Dallas62130926
top_replies.text: Per capita electricity demand is still lower in China so they aren't actually ahead. But still Elon is taking about terawatt scale orbital data centres which is going to put xAI way in the lead.

top_replies.author: _Anai_x
top_replies.text: It is kinda expected considering that other countries moved their production there.

top_replies.author: todayinai_
top_replies.text: AI training alone consumed ~15 TWh in 2023, equivalent to a small country. This rate of energy demand growth, primarily driven by massive data centers, requires immediate global grid expansion to sustain the current AI trajectory.

top_replies.author: Akhi_l__
top_replies.text:
China knows the game  that's why they prioritized energy investment early on.

 Now, that investment is helping AI grow rapidly..

top_replies.author: TheAIFlow
top_replies.text: People obsess over energy use for AI training. They ignore that electricity is already the limiting factor for most businesses. The real story is who controls cheap power wins the race. China understood this years ago

top_replies.author: RexBruv
top_replies.text: Is it consumption or production? Or maybe both?

top_replies.author: Qutossar
top_replies.text: It is not that hard to consume electricity. What is hard is to use it efficiently...

hnology/bezos-project-prometheus.html?partner=slack&smid=sl-share
â€¦

Everyone thinks Google will drop the price of Gemini 3.0 to zero because their chips (TPUs) are so cheap.

I ran the game theory on this, and I think we have it backwards.

Google actually has the strongest incentive to keep AI expensive. Hereâ€™s the trap. 

1/ The "Obvious" Logic:

Google owns the chips (TPUs). They don't pay the "Nvidia Tax" (75% margins) like OpenAI does.

Therefore, their internal cost to run AI is ~50% lower.

Standard playbook: Drop the price, kill the competitor, win the market.

2/ But Google isn't playing a standard price war.

They have a $200B hostage that OpenAI doesn't have:
Search Revenue.

3/ To understand the game, look at the Unit Economics:

â€¢ Search: You search â†’ Google shows 10 links + Ads â†’ You click â†’ Google makes money. Cost: Near zero.

â€¢ AI: You ask â†’ Gemini writes a perfect paragraph â†’ You read it and leave. Google makes $0. Cost: High.

4/ This is the "Cannibalization Trap."

If Google makes their AI incredibly smart, cheap, and fast, people stop Googling things. They start Chatting things.

Google would be effectively trading high-margin Ad dollars for negative-margin AI pennies.

5/ This is the textbook "Innovator's Dilemma."

If Google drives the price of "Intelligence" to zero, they accidentally detonate their own Golden Goose.

They need AI to remain a premium, expensive enterprise add-onâ€”at least until they figure out how to put ads inside a chat response.

6/ So, whatâ€™s the optimal move? The "Price Umbrella."

OpenAI has to charge ~$20/1M tokens because they have to pay Nvidia.

Google loves this. It sets a high "anchor price" for the market.

7/ Instead of undercutting OpenAI by 90% (which they could afford), Google will undercut them by just 10%.

They draft behind OpenAIâ€™s high prices, pocketing the massive margin difference without destroying the perceived value of "information."

8/ Thereâ€™s also a regulatory gun to their head.

If Google dropped the price to $0.01 tomorrow, they would bankrupt every AI startup instantly.

The DOJ is already watching them. "Predatory Pricing" to kill competition is the fastest way to get broken up. High prices keep the heat off.

9/ Prediction: Watch for the "Bifurcation."

Google will split the strategy:
â€¢ Gemini Ultra: Kept expensive. Protects the "premium" feel. Keeps Search safe.

â€¢ Gemini Flash: Dirt cheap. This is the weapon they use to kill competitors in the low-end utility market.

10/ The takeaway:

Donâ€™t hold your breath for "free" GPT-5 class models from Google.

They aren't priced based on the cost of silicon.

They are priced based on the cost of replacing a $200B ad monopoly.

bookmarks.text:
Michael Burry, the guy who predicted the 2008 housing crisis, just called out Big Tech for padding their profits through accounting tricks. He's saying companies like Meta and Alphabet are making their earnings look better by claiming their computing equipment lasts longer than it actually does. Meta extended its useful life estimates from five years to five and a half years, which magically reduces their 2025 costs by $2.9 billion without changing anything about the actual business.

The Spending Reality
The four biggest AI spenders are projected to boost combined spending by 40% to $460 billion in the next 12 months. Depreciation expenses are skyrocketing even with the accounting moves. Alphabet, Microsoft and Meta combined for about $10 billion in depreciation costs in Q4 2023. The quarter ending September hit nearly $22 billion. By next year, analysts expect almost $30 billion. Meta is up just 4.2% in 2025, far below the 19% Nasdaq 100 rise, and down 17% in the second half.

My Take
I think Burry's onto something here. When companies say their equipment lasts longer, they spread the cost over more years, which makes current profits look better on paper without actually earning more money. Meta saving $2.9 billion by extending equipment life half a year means their profits look $2.9 billion better for doing nothing. The question is whether that's realistic when Nvidia releases new chips faster, making old ones obsolete quicker. Amazon doesn't think so, they shortened equipment life from six years to five. These companies are spending $460 billion on AI infrastructure while depreciation costs jumped from $10 billion to $22 billion quarterly, headed to $30 billion. When Meta is up just 4.2% while spending massive amounts and using accounting to boost profits, that's what Burry is flagging. The profits beat expectations, but are they real or inflated by claiming equipment lasts longer than it does?

Hedgie

top_replies.text: Yaar, Hedgie is right to point out Burry's warning, it's a serious matter, and these big tech accounting tricks are a bit fishy, no?

top_replies.text:
This is nothing new and won't have any material effect on the orgs.

18 months from now, they will have a new grift going and this will all get buried.

They are too big to be investigated.

top_replies.text:
They are using Nvidia chips as collateral.

These normally are depreciated to zero over 3 years because of obsolecence.

They are deprecating the chips over 6 years in some cases.

top_replies.author: gerdy03766
top_replies.text: I am all about ferreting out fraud, but if Big Tech actually USES their equipment for the longer period their accounting is accurate. In healthcare for example capital equipment is almost always used beyond "useful life."

top_replies.author: AllTrump7766
top_replies.text: But if they said they only last three years then they would be accused of taking depreciation earlier.

top_replies.author: rafaelision
top_replies.text: Big tech profit is real but feature investments are questionable so all you can get is corrections

top_replies.author: TitanTrader911
top_replies.text: Just as concerning is they just took out $30 B in debt but placed it off balance sheet in an SPV. Hiding their debt in an SPV makes their balance sheet look stronger  lowering debt to equity. Same thing Enron did. Ask yourself why are they hiding it in a SPV?

ã‚¢ãƒ«ãƒˆãƒãƒ³ã€Œãã†æ€ã„ã¾ã™ã€

John von Neumann mightâ€™ve been the most brilliant human who ever lived.

Hereâ€™s what just one mind - John von Neumann contributed to humanity (after reading the list imagine a world with billions of minds of this quality).

AI will soon give us billions of John von Neumanns.

Mathematics

Set theory: Developed the von Neumann universe (cumulative hierarchy), a foundational concept in modern set theory.

Ordinal numbers: Introduced the von Neumann construction of ordinals and cardinals.

Functional analysis: Contributed to the development of operator theory and Hilbert spaces, essential for quantum mechanics.

Ergodic theory: Founded ergodic theory, which studies statistical behavior in dynamical systems.

Measure theory: Advanced the modern mathematical treatment of measure and integration.

Computer Science

Von Neumann architecture: Proposed the fundamental design of almost all modern computers, with a central processing unit (CPU), memory, and stored programs.

Stored program concept: Suggested that both data and instructions could reside in memory, a revolutionary idea that made general purpose computing possible.

EDVAC report (1945): Authored the first formal description of a modern computer system, influencing the design of ENIAC, EDVAC, and future computers.

Foundations of numerical analysis: Developed methods for solving complex mathematical problems with digital computers.

Self replicating automata: Conceived the idea of self replicating machines, a foundation for artificial life, cellular automata, and nanotechnology.

Physics

Quantum mechanics: Formulated the mathematical foundations of quantum theory in his 1932 book Mathematical Foundations of Quantum Mechanics.

Introduced Hilbert space formalism for quantum mechanics.

Developed von Neumann entropy, linking quantum mechanics and information theory.

Contributed to quantum statistical mechanics and the concept of quantum logic.

Played a major role in the Manhattan Project, helping to model nuclear explosions and shock waves.

Worked on hydrodynamics and explosion theory (vital for both nuclear weapons and early astrophysics).

Economics & Game Theory

Founded game theory with his 1928 paper On the Theory of Games of Strategy.

Co authored Theory of Games and Economic Behavior (1944) with Oskar Morgenstern, the cornerstone of modern economics and strategic decision theory.

Developed the minimax theorem, fundamental to competitive strategy.

Introduced expected utility theory, now core to economics and psychology.

Pioneered general equilibrium theory and economic modeling.

Logic & Philosophy

Contributed to mathematical logic and the foundations of mathematics, extending the ideas of Hilbert and GÃ¶del.

Worked on proof theory, formal systems, and the axiomatization of set theory.

Anticipated ideas about AI and machine cognition, discussing self modifying machines and intelligent automata decades ahead of their time.

Engineering & Applied Science

He was key figure in early aerodynamics and shockwave theory, contributing to supersonic and hypersonic flight research.

Developed computer simulations for fluid dynamics, precursors to modern computational physics.

Consulted for the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission and played a strategic role in nuclear and thermonuclear weapon development.

Early advocate of automation and computing in engineering.

He inspired entire fields: computer architecture, AI, game theory, quantum information, and complex systems.

The term "von Neumann machine" still refers to modern computer design.

His ideas on self replication anticipated DNAâ€™s informational structure and modern synthetic biology.

Credited with envisioning the singularity like acceleration of technological progress due to computing power.

bookmarks.text:
The first preview of "Group chats" in the ChatGPT web app

- the top navigation bar now has a "Start a group chat" button which allows you to generate a link and share it with others to join this group chat shown in the new sidebar section "Group chats"

- anyone can join your group chat with this link, and they'll be able to see the previous messages in this group chat

- group chats custom instructions are separate from custom instructions for your personal ChatGPT, and you can let ChatGPT respond automatically or only when mentioned by someone in the group chat, but your personal ChatGPT memory is never used in group chats

- the web app assets also mention options to add reactions, report or reply to a specific message, an indicator when someone is typing, file uploads, image creation and web search

 Anthropic just solved the problem every AI agent engineerâ€™s been screaming about for a year.

Every agent today burns tokens like fuel every tool call, every definition, every intermediate result jammed into context.

Now Anthropicâ€™s introducing the fix: code execution with MCP.

Instead of calling tools directly, agents now write code to call them and it changes everything.

â†’ 98.7% fewer tokens
â†’ 10x faster task completion
â†’ No context overload
â†’ No data leakage

Think of it like this:

Old agents talk about what to do. New agents just code and do it.

Cloudflare calls it â€œCode Mode.â€ Anthropic just made it real.

This is the turning point.

The next generation of AI agents wonâ€™t prompt tools theyâ€™ll build with them.

AIã®åˆ¶ç´„ã¯ã‚‚ã¯ã‚„GPUã§ã¯ãªãé›»åŠ›ã¨ãƒ‡ãƒ¼ã‚¿ã‚»ãƒ³ã‚¿ãƒ¼ã€‚ãƒã‚¤ã‚¯ãƒ­ã‚½ãƒ•ãƒˆã®ãƒŠãƒ‡ãƒ©CEOã¯ã€Œé›»åŠ›ä¸è¶³ã§H100ãŒç¨¼åƒã§ããªã„ã€ã¨æ˜ã‹ã—ã€AIæŠ•è³‡ãƒ¢ãƒ‡ãƒ«ã®å‰æãŒå´©ã‚ŒãŸã€‚GPUã¯å¹´1å›ã§é™³è…åŒ–ã—ã€ç¨¼åƒã¾ã§ã®é…ã‚ŒãŒæå¤±ã¨ãªã‚‹ã€‚AIã®ç«¶äº‰å„ªä½ã¯æŠ€è¡“ã§ã¯ãªãã‚¨ãƒãƒ«ã‚®ãƒ¼ã¨ç‰©ç†ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ•ãƒ©ã«ç§»ã£ãŸã€‚

Anthropic has overtaken OpenAI in enterprise LLM API market share.

OpenAI fell from 50% in late 2023 to 25% by mid-2025, which shows that brand alone does not hold share once real workloads start.

Anthropic now leads enterprise LLM API usage with 32%, while OpenAI has 25%, pointing to a real shift in how companies pick vendors.

Enterprise LLM API spend hit $8.4B in the first half of 2025.

Anthropicâ€™s push on data controls, compliance, and clean integration with existing systems won trust, and that trust tends to decide renewals and expansions.

Claudeâ€™s recent lines, including stronger reasoning and coding, helped too, with developer code-gen share around 42% for Anthropic vs 21% for OpenAI.

Usage is shifting to inference at scale, so uptime, latency, and incident response matter more than raw benchmark wins.

Vendor switching stayed low at 11%, and 66% of teams just upgraded within the same vendor, so any share gain here is hard won.

Google sits near 20% and Meta near 9%, so this is not a 2-player market, and strengths differ by use case like agents, code, or retrieval.

Buyers now weigh cost per token, data residency, auditability, SOC reports, and fine-grained controls as much as model quality.

Multi-vendor setups are rising because they reduce lock-in and let teams route tasks to the best model for that job.

bookmarks.text:
THIS IS WHAT'S KEEPING ME UP AT NIGHT:

1. AI will kill the concept of a 9â€“5 for millions. MANY get laid off, become freelancers, shift to portfolios of agent-assisted work.

2. livestreaming explodes 100Ã—. it becomes the only way to prove you are real and not AI. Twitch will look like one of the greatest acquisitions of all time. 

3. the creator economy is graduating into the founder economy. audiences are mobilizing into companies, funds, and franchises. MrBeast was just the prototype! 

4. weâ€™re entering the app recombination era. the biggest startups of 2026 will be built by remixing three or four existing AI tools into new vertical workflows.

5. agents will start talking to other agents, and you wonâ€™t be in the loop. every â€œhuman in the middleâ€ job becomes an API call between two models.

6. AI is collapsing the value chain. agencies, recruiters, consultants, and project managers disappear while micro-operators running ten-agent stacks take their place.

7. distribution goes agentic. every AI company will run a thousand influencer agents testing titles, thumbnails, and CTAs nonstop. ad spend becomes a living organism. i hope you like testing.

8. personalization flips commerce. the same product sells for fifty prices through fifty custom funnels, each built by AI for that buyer. price discovery becomes dynamic. this is prob better for business owners and worse for consumers :( .

9. data privacy becomes the new luxury. entire brands form around â€œhuman-only,â€ â€œno-model,â€ or â€œoffline verified.â€ authenticity becomes a trillion-dollar aesthetic.

10. creators will own AI studios instead of channels. one prompt becomes a short, an app, a brand, a product line. the boundary between content and company disappears.

11. the big social platforms fracture into signal markets. people will trade ideas, audience data, and prompt assets the way day-traders swap stocks. virality gets financialized. already happening.

12. energy becomes the next constraint. every AI boom ends in a power bottleneck. whoever solves cheap, local compute with solar or geothermal wins the century.

13. storytelling becomes an economic engine again. the only moats left are narrative, taste, and trust.

14. AI-native insurance becomes a massive opportunity. once agents handle billions of decisions, someone must underwrite the risk.

15. an AI glut means deflation everywhere except in ideas. when intelligence is free, originality becomes priceless.

16. governments create national models to protect sovereignty. data turns into a weapon and compute becomes foreign policy.

17. as agents handle logistics, humans move up the stack into aesthetics. art direction becomes a daily skill. everything becomes branding.

18. the next decadeâ€™s wealth comes not just from building AI but from deciding where not to use it. restraint will make fortunes.

19. AI compute arbitrage becomes a trillion-dollar trade. people buy cheap cloud in underdeveloped markets and rent it globally, like Airbnb for GPUs.

20. AI-native brands dominate e-commerce by owning micro-trends. they launch new products daily, test a thousand ad variants, and kill losers overnight.

21. the AI gold rush ends with a massive data rush. whoever owns or licenses niche, verified datasets controls the supply chain of the future.

22. the next $10 billion fund is hybrid: part VC, part compute allocator, part data warehouse. capital moves from money to intelligence.

23. once personal AGIs hit, subscription fatigue dies. consumers will want one AI that handles everything. the first â€œsuper-app for lifeâ€ could be a trillion-dollar company.

24. most billion-dollar outcomes this decade come from repackaging existing industries through AI... the AI accountant, AI real-estate broker, AI logistics coordinator starting as highly vertical versions of familiar services.

25. mobile UI shifts from taps to chat + camera. the screen becomes a lens, the conversation becomes the interface. the app era quietly turns into the agent era. 
@meetLCA
 is a design agency i co-founded that is behind the biggest AI apps rn, seeing it play out now.

26. every industry is about to unbundle into interface companies. whoever owns the customer interface, not the backend or the model, controls the value chain. itâ€™s Shopify vs AWS all over again.

27. vertical media merges with vertical SaaS. every niche publication births a product; every software company births a content arm. the media-product line disappears.

28. the internet used to reward consistency. the new internet rewards experimentation. the faster you test, the faster you compound.

29. AI blurs the line between work and art. products start to feel authored, like albums or films. founders become creative directors of automation.

30. AI regulation prob will look like climate policy... too slow, too messy, full of loopholes. innovation moves to places that treat compute like oil.

31. the internet fragments into private ecosystems. niche communities curated by AI become the real web. public feeds feel like Times Square; private groups feel like homes!!

32. the first fully autonomous startup launches within 3 years. no employees, no meetings, no deadlines, just connected agents generating profit. insanity.

33. we are living through the great compression. timelines that used to unfold over decades now happen in months. this is the closest thing to a gold rush most people will ever see.

34. people will look back on 2026â€“2029 the way we look at the early internet. the difference is you donâ€™t need permission, capital, or credentials. you just need to build something people actually care about.

35. mobile consumer apps feel alive again. they talk back, remember you, and evolve with you. static interfaces begin to feel prehistoric.

36. the next decade of wealth will belong to people who understand three things: distribution is leverage, taste is strategy, and AI is infrastructure.

im tired because i havent slept but wired because...

THIS IS THE BEST TIME IN HISTORY TO BUILD.

our future will look very different than our past/present. life as we know it changing.

i hope you get some sleep.

There is a lot of excitement about the comment. However, it ignores the fact that work has always changed â€“ and inefficient professions have ceased to exist over time. A few thoughts on this.

It is hard to imagine today, but when street lamps were still powered by gas, there was a profession called lamp lighter. Obviously, this is no longer necessary today.

And the same thing will happen â€“ only on a much larger scale â€“ to numerous professions in the near future. Apart from truly specialised professionals, simple white-collar jobs will almost certainly be decimated at first, because one person acting as the conductor of numerous agents will be completely replaced in the future.

And that's not a bad thing! We should welcome the fact that AI is taking on tedious work for us. What's more, we will have more free time to devote to creative activities; people will seek out new challenges or social problems and strive to find solutions. Humans are creative, active beings. I am convinced that boredom will not set in. And even if, as in Star Trek, people now see their task as exploring the unknown.

What people are rightly concerned about, however, is the loss of their income. This concern is indeed justified. And a solution is indeed needed. But that is a social issue that can be resolved. All other concerns are unfounded.

Even if 99% of music or films are generated by AI in the future, people will still get out their guitars and sing songs together with their friends, because humans are social beings and enjoy singing and dancing. The only concern is the marketing of art and culture in terms of generating income. And again, this concern is indeed justified and must be resolved.

Otherwise, we should welcome, promote and accelerate the technological revolution. Because we cannot oppose it anyway.

Here are two very important charts about the current AI boom. 

Chart 1: Distribution Matters

Open AI is still the clear leader but, interestingly, they are loosing percentage share as the market grows. This is normal for a category leader but itâ€™s curious who they are losing share to. Itâ€™s not really to other startups but incumbents with existing, massive distribution. This means that Google has a huge runway ahead of itself as their models and services become better. It also means that when/if Meta gets their act together, they will be able to gain share quickly. Lastly, it likely means that xAI will need to license Grok aggressively OR acquire existing distribution for their models - Snapchat, Pinterest etc.

Chart 2: Coding Agents are Slopware App-crappers

It should be concerning that this category is shrinking. I think the reason why is obvious but we arenâ€™t allowed to talk about it. 

The reason is vibe coding is a joke. 

It is deeply unserious and these tools arenâ€™t delivering when they encounter real world complexity (building quick demos isnâ€™t complex) in any meaningful enterprise. 

Hence people try, pay, churn. This trend is not good.

Here's the 15 skills that Anthropic pre-packaged.

Each one is essentially a long pre-defined prompt for a specific task, a hybrid between a custom system prompt and a lightweight MCP.

So far, I've found it useful for basic tasks like:
â€” Consistent themes in my brand
â€” Generating text with my guidelines
â€” Using certain esoteric coding libraries the way they should be

The paper proposes a concrete test for AGI by checking if an AI matches a well educated adult across 10 abilities.

And reading it, the obvious conclusion is we are just so far away from AGI level intelligence.

They report an â€œAGI Scoreâ€ and show GPT-4 at 27% and GPT-5 at 58%, with long term memory at 0%.

The goal is to stop the moving target problem and make progress measurable and auditable.

They ground the checklist in the Cattell Horn Carroll model, a long standing map of human cognitive abilities.

The 10 areas cover knowledge, reading and writing, math, on the spot reasoning, working memory, long term memory storage, long term memory retrieval, visual processing, auditory processing, and speed.

Each area is tested with focused subtests such as deduction, induction, theory of mind, planning, visual rotation, phonetic coding, and reaction time.

Instead of only big end tasks, they adapt human style subtests that isolate narrow skills like induction, theory of mind, planning, visual rotation, phonetic coding, and reaction times.

Modern models look very strong on knowledge, language, and math, and weak on vision, audio, speed, and storing and recalling new facts without errors.

They show that todayâ€™s systems often fake memory by stuffing huge context windows and fake precise recall by leaning on retrieval from external tools, which hides real gaps in storing new facts and recalling them without hallucinations.

They emphasize that both GPT-4 and GPT-5 fail to form lasting memories across sessions and still mix in wrong facts when retrieving, which limits dependable learning and personalization over days or weeks.

The scope is cognitive ability, not motor control or economic output, so a high score does not guarantee business value.

They warn about training contamination and push for small distribution shifts and human checks when grading.

In summary, progress will stall without durable long term memory and precise retrieval, because the weakest part limits the system.

THE PENTAGONâ€™S $1 BILLION METAL BINGE

The Pentagon just went shopping - and itâ€™s not for missiles. Itâ€™s for minerals.

In a quiet but massive move, the Defense Department is stockpiling $1 billion worth of critical metals - cobalt, antimony, tantalum, scandium - the invisible ingredients behind F-35s, radar systems, and missile guidance tech.

Why? Because China owns the market, and Beijing just tightened export controls on rare earths again. 

Trumpâ€™s response: tariffs, canceled meetings with Xi, and a rush to secure every ounce of non-Chinese supply on Earth.

According to filings, the Defense Logistics Agency is hoarding materials at levels not seen since the Cold War. 

Some contracts:

$500M in cobalt
$245M in antimony from U.S. Antimony Corp
$100M in tantalum
$45M in scandium - half the planetâ€™s annual supply

Analysts call the volumes â€œunrealistic.â€ Meaning: the Pentagonâ€™s trying to buy more metal than the West can even mine.

Trumpâ€™s One Big Beautiful Bill Act pumps $7.5B into the mineral race, with $2B for stockpiles alone.

This isnâ€™t about batteries or green tech anymore - itâ€™s economic war prep. Whoever controls the metals controls the machines.

And right now, the Pentagonâ€™s building a future where America doesnâ€™t have to ask Beijing for permission to make a fighter jet.

Source: FT

Summary of AMA with OpenAI on DevDay 2025 Launches (2025-10-09)

AgentKit Development and Deployment Strategy

- Want to make agents more easily discoverable and usable within companies to start, agent store would be cool

- Agent Builder lets you quickly preview workflows, set up evals, collaborate with stakeholders, then export to Agents SDK which works with any model via built-in LiteLLM support

- Planning to support deployment of workflows as standalone API with webhook triggers and streamlined ChatGPT deployment, want to support importing Agents SDK-created agents back into Agent Builder

- When deploying hosted Agent Builder workflow, existing rate limits automatically apply with conversation context preserved within thread allowing multi-turn interactions up to model's maximum context window

- For high concurrency, main thing you can do besides standard CPU/memory scaling is gracefully handle rate limits for model calls, thinking about durable execution for OpenAI-executed workflows which would handle this automatically

- Can use variety of context management strategies within Agents SDK including filtering out older input items, plans to support range of these in Agent Builder runtime

Codex CLI Roadmap and Capabilities

- Plan to keep CLI as top priority with no plans to cut Pro limits, goal remains high enough to use Codex as daily coding agent for full workweek

- Thinking about Plan mode, looking at background bash so Codex can run API server and test it, edit code, run again for autonomous loop, considering hooks but no firm decisions yet on best solution

- Constantly tuning sandbox and planning to ship permanent allowlisting of commands, planning to roll out much better authflow today or tomorrow for device code login

- Exciting updates will come within next 6-12 months on codebase level understanding, learning over time, helping humans understand and onboard, being proactive in spotting opportunities and sending fixes

- All agents too scared of exceptions and unable to leverage interactive debuggers like gdb, thinking about solving this more generally as life is not all about Python, lots of open research questions still for parallel subagents

Codex SDK Integration and Tool Support

- Codex SDK simplest when task is something Codex can handle end to end, usually coding related tasks like code Q&A, codegen, bug triage; if building more complex workflow with handoffs between multiple agents beyond Codex, Agents SDK is the way to go

- Multiple customers use Codex as one of the agents inside Agents SDK workflows

- Plan spec from Shipping With Codex event available in OpenAI cookbook repository, app-server code in Codex Rust repository shows protocol that powers IDE extension, shipped GitHub Action that can serve as template for BitBucket Pipeline integration

- Going to continuously improve Codex SDK, shipped Codex Slack app on Monday, now super hard at work on improving Windows support across the board with expectation to see incremental improvements over coming weeks

Model Access and Performance

- GPT-5 Pro coming to Codex via ChatGPT account, though bear in mind by default it will think longer and use rate limits faster than GPT-5-Codex, with some ideas for how to make most of GPT-5 Pro in Codex, should already have all same tool use as GPT-5 in ChatGPT

- Using medium reasoning or GPT-5-Codex should both be faster options, latency definitely top of mind, option where models run faster is fun idea thrown around few times but no concrete plans at this time

- Priority API not yet available in Codex CLI, opted for GPT-4.1 for DevDay demo since likely to be faster for setup and needed file search which isn't yet supported on GPT-5 with minimal reasoning

Sora 2 API Capabilities and Limitations

- Sora 2 in API available in all countries where OpenAI API is currently live including Philippines, while Sora App access currently limited to United States and Canada only

- Can use image references to guide video generation in API, though currently doesn't natively support arbitrary input image sizes with automatic letterboxing, can achieve same effect by pre-processing image before uploading using tools like ffmpeg or lightweight Python/JavaScript scripts, have logged this as feature request

- Current guardrails are real people including public figures cannot be generated and input images with faces of humans currently rejected, but possible to generate realistic fictional people

- For image generation can currently use gpt-image-1 or gpt-image-1-mini which offers quality and latency comparable to gpt-image-1, input fidelity not supported with mini model, not currently on roadmap for local variant as open models today are text-based only

bookmarks.text:
OpenAI employee:

"the agent builder we released today was built end-to-end in under six weeks, with Codex writing 80% of the PRs"

this matches the AI-2027 report's 2026 forecast:

- coding automation goes mainstream
- agents work like teammates
- AI R&D is 50% faster from algorithms, not just compute

top_replies.author: lehoho248
top_replies.text: what's crazy is that half of these replies seem to be LLM responses

top_replies.author: carlosml
top_replies.text: AI writing 80% of PRs in 6 weeks? At this rate, devs are just glorified debuggers

top_replies.author: AIxBlock
top_replies.text: AI R&D flywheel is spinning. Agents write, test, and ship, humans just set direction.

top_replies.author: AIxBlock
top_replies.text:
Insane velocity. 
When agents start co-authoring codebases, shipping cycles compress from quarters to weeks.
Weâ€™re not just accelerating compute, weâ€™re accelerating creation itself.

top_replies.author: TKiselchuk
top_replies.text: This redefines development. When agents write 80% of PRs, the bottleneck shifts from implementation to architecture. Teams become curators rather than coders. The real shift: human-AI pairing at the design level, with humans focused on "what and why" while AI handles "how."

top_replies.author: LexanderBrouwer
top_replies.text: Itâ€™s a first step - itâ€™s only the tech leaders that do this right now, will take a while till large orgs adopt that way of working as well.

top_replies.author: cornfuzed
top_replies.text: Thatâ€™s crazy. I would have guessed 2 weeks based on how bad it sucks.

bookmarks.text:
Sam Altman on Sora, Energy, and Building an AI Empire

From GPT-5 to Sora, OpenAI has been making a dizzying amount of bets recently. It now acts as a frontier AGI research lab, a big tech product company with nearly a billion users, and a driver of the largest infrastructure buildout in history, all in one - plus, itâ€™s made partnerships with Microsoft, Nvidia, Oracle, AMD, SoftBank, Oracle, and even the US government.

We talked to Sam Altman about the core thesis bringing OpenAIâ€™s bets together, why they released Sora, how they use models internally, the most informative evals for assessing AI progress, and where weâ€™re going from here.

00:00  Introduction
00:41  OpenAIâ€™s vision
08:01  Human-AI interfaces
09:28  AI scientists and scientific progress
17:52  Sam's operating lessons
28:33  Copyright and open source
43:03  AI talent wars
45:33  Advice for founders

"100 million words context window is already possible, which is roughly what a human hears in a lifetime. Inference support is the only bottleneck to achieve it.

And AI Models actually do learn during the context window, without changing the weights."

~ Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei

(On the 2nd point, there was this brilliant Google Paper published last week that says, LLMs can learn in context from examples in the prompt,  can pick up new patterns while answering, yet their stored weights never change.)

---
From 'Alex Kantrowitz' YT Channel (Full Video link in comment)

What are current economic models missing about AGI? How would we know if we were approaching explosive growth?

Stanford economist Phil Trammell has been rigorously thinking about the intersection of economic theory and AI (incl. AGI) for over five years, long before the recent surge of interest in large language models.

In this episode of Epoch After Hours, 
@pawtrammell
 and Epoch AI researcher 
@ansonwhho
 discuss what economic theory really has to say about the development and impacts of AGI: what current economic models get wrong, the odds of explosive economic growth, what â€œreal GDPâ€ actually measures, and much more!

-- Timestamps --
0:00:00 - Problems with existing work on the economics of AI
0:10:18 - Declining returns to R&D
0:18:28 - What real GDP misses
0:26:57 - Task-based models & AI automation
0:49:32 - The limits of economic theory
1:09:11 - How to detect an economic singularity
1:23:32 - Increasing returns to scale

Sam Altmanâ€™s playbook is clear:

When a model becomes usable, OpenAI rushes to turn it into a blockbuster app:

ChatGPT â€“ chat app
Codex â€“ coding app
Sora â€“ video app

bookmarks.text:
AI Faces Glass Fiber Shortageâ€¦ Industry Struggles as Japan Monopolizes Key Material

    â€¢ The industry is on high alert due to a shortage of low thermal expansion glass fiber used in AI semiconductor substrates.

    â€¢ Demand is surging, but the number of suppliers worldwide is extremely limited. Capacity expansion also takes a long time, so the shortage of glass fiber is hitting the advanced industries hard.

    â€¢ Low thermal expansion glass fiber has effectively become â€œname your price.â€ Manufacturers are allocating supply by customer and raising prices.

    â€¢ In the case of Japanâ€™s Nittobo, the price of its low thermal expansion glass fiber has already risen by around 20% since August, with the possibility of further hikes being raised.

    â€¢ With supply so scarce, securing volumes has become urgent even if prices rise. Not only substrate-related companies but also semiconductor firms, the ultimate customers, are sending executives abroadâ€”essentially waging a â€œglass fiber procurement war.â€

    â€¢ An industry insider explained: â€œNittoboâ€™s product has effectively become the industry standard, but supply is limited and constrained. Companies are lining up to receive allocations, and even top executives are now directly stepping in.â€

    â€¢ Glass fiber is one of the materials used in CCL (copper-clad laminate), the main substrate material. It resembles bundles of fine glass threads and is used to enhance substrate heat resistance.

    â€¢ For high-performance AI semiconductors, glass fiber is indispensable, as they generate far more heat than conventional semiconductors and require high-temperature advanced packaging processes. This makes glass fiber both necessary and in larger volumes.

    â€¢ With the explosive growth of the AI market and skyrocketing demand for high-performance chips, bottlenecks have emerged in the glass fiber supply chain, creating cracks in supply-demand balance.

    â€¢ Only a handful of companies manufacture low thermal expansion glass fiber, including Japanâ€™s Nittobo and Taiwan Glass, but Nittobo dominates the market with over 80% global share.

    â€¢ Nittoboâ€™s flagship glass fiber, â€œT-Glass,â€ first gained attention in 2023 in AI server switch motherboards and then saw demand soar in AI semiconductor substrates the following year.

    â€¢ In Korea, Doosan Electronics and LG Chem use T-Glass to produce CCL, which they then supply to substrate manufacturers.

    â€¢ The shortage of low thermal expansion glass fiber is not expected to ease easily and may continue through next year, raising concerns about industry-wide impact.

    â€¢ As a latecomer, Taiwan Glass is attempting to enter the supply chain, but its quality and capacity expansion are reportedly not progressing smoothly. Meanwhile, Nittobo is pushing to expand, but new facilities are only expected to begin operations in 2027.

Today, 
@ekindogus
 and I are excited to introduce 
@periodiclabs
.

Our goal is to create an AI scientist.

Science works by conjecturing how the world might be, running experiments, and learning from the results.

Intelligence is necessary, but not sufficient. New knowledge is created when ideas are found to be consistent with reality. And so, at Periodic, we are building AI scientists and the autonomous laboratories for them to operate.

Until now, scientific AI advances have come from models trained on the internet. But despite its vastness â€” itâ€™s still finite (estimates are ~10T text tokens where one English word may be 1-2 tokens). And in recent years the best frontier AI models have fully exhausted it.

Researchers seek better use of this data, but as any scientist knows: though re-reading a textbook may give new insights, they eventually need to try their idea to see if it holds.

Autonomous labs are central to our strategy. They provide huge amounts of high-quality data (each experiment can produce GBs of data!) that exists nowhere else. They generate valuable negative results which are seldom published. But most importantly, they give our AI scientists the tools to act.
Weâ€™re starting in the physical sciences.

Technological progress is limited by our ability to design the physical world.

Weâ€™re starting here because experiments have high signal-to-noise and are (relatively) fast, physical simulations effectively model many systems, but more broadly, physics is a verifiable environment. AI has progressed fastest in domains with data and verifiable results - for example, in math and code. Here, nature is the RL environment.

One of our goals is to discover superconductors that work at higher temperatures than today's materials. Significant advances could help us create next-generation transportation and build power grids with minimal losses. But this is just one example â€” if we can automate materials design, we have the potential to accelerate Mooreâ€™s Law, space travel, and nuclear fusion.

Weâ€™re also working to deploy our solutions with industry. As an example, we're helping a semiconductor manufacturer that is facing issues with heat dissipation on their chips. Weâ€™re training custom agents for their engineers and researchers to make sense of their experimental data in order to iterate faster.

Our founding team co-created ChatGPT, DeepMindâ€™s GNoME, OpenAIâ€™s Operator (now Agent), the neural attention mechanism, MatterGen; have scaled autonomous physics labs; and have contributed to some of the most important materials discoveries of the last decade. Weâ€™ve come together to scale up and reimagine how science is done.

Weâ€™re fortunate to be backed by investors who share our vision, including 
@a16z
  who led our $300M round, as well as 
@Felicis
, DST Global, NVentures (NVIDIAâ€™s venture capital arm), 
@Accel
 and individuals including 
@JeffBezos
 , 
@eladgil
 , 
@ericschmidt
, and 
@JeffDean
. Their support will help us grow our team, scale our labs, and develop the first generation of AI scientists.

$FLNC - AI is fueling the biggest infrastructure boom of our lifetime. Everyone is focused on GPUs but none of it runs without power.

Data centers driving the AI revolution donâ€™t just need electricity. They need flexible, reliable, high-density energy storage to balance the grid and keep servers running 24/7. Thatâ€™s where Fluenceâ€™s Smartstackâ„¢ comes in.

Smartstackâ„¢ isnâ€™t just another containerized battery system. It delivers:

 30% higher density â€” critical when land and space around hyperscale data centers are limited

 Modular design â€” enabling faster, cheaper installation and scaling with demand

 Industry-leading performance guarantees â€” reducing risk for operators making billion-dollar AI power commitments

With production underway at Fluenceâ€™s state-of-the-art automated facility, Smartstackâ„¢ is being built at scale to meet surging demand.

As AI accelerates global power needs, the winners wonâ€™t just be chipmakers, theyâ€™ll be the companies making the grid smarter, cleaner, and more reliable.
Fluence is positioning itself to be one of them.

AI 2026: Schrittweisers analysis

Julian Schrittweiser has provided a very catchy but at the same time plausible outlook for AI over the next two years.

In short: instead of listening to all the different "experts," we should just look at the data. METR has shown that the amount of work that AI can perform virtually independently is increasing exponentially; by mid-2026, AI models will be able to work an entire day (8 hours) on their own.

The latest benchmark from OpenAI shows that even relatively old models (old meaning two months old) can already perform nearly 50% of the tasks of a skilled worker with around 14 years of work experience (real-world-task benchmark)

In short, 2026 will see a major shift in the world of work, as AI models will be able to match the expertise of skilled workers in real-world tasks and work independently for eight hours. It is difficult to predict how this will develop by 2027. 

Highly recommend your read his blogarticle

top_replies.author: petergostev
top_replies.text: In terms of how it was made - nothing complicated, just ask Codex to make a visualisaiton in HTML, or you can ask for React too, but a bit more complex to run. In this case it is using D3 js libary. I usually ask for light colours (since LLMs like dark neon ones for some reason).

A single-digit percent of their capacity could be enough for a whole country.

Sam Altman predicts a tipping point:

By 2030, artificial general intelligence could surpass human intelligence.

If AI isnâ€™t aligned with human values, we risk creating something far smarter than us but indifferent to us.

Thatâ€™s less than 5 years away.

Game-changing progress or an existential gamble?

top_replies.author: MichaelMaiello

By 2045, Kurzweilâ€™s â€œSingularityâ€ wonâ€™t just be a metaphor, itâ€™ll be the operating system of civilization.

On the AI side, the trendlines are undeniable: models are rapidly leaping from solving problems in minutes to problems that would take humans centuries. By mid-century, AIs will be tackling tasks that would otherwise take millions of years of human effort. Thatâ€™s not hype, thatâ€™s what the scaling laws and benchmarks already project.

On the robotics side, the Bank of America forecast shows humanoid robots reaching into the billions by 2060, with mass household, service, and industrial adoption. By the 2040s, weâ€™ll have enough robots to fully automate the supply chain, factories, and every repetitive or dangerous job. The â€œhandsâ€ of civilization will be robotic, and the â€œmindâ€ will be superintelligent AI.

That convergence is the singularity. A world where labor is optional, scarcity is engineered out of existence, and problems that haunted humanity for millennia, from climate to disease are solved in decades.

Kurzweil said it would arrive around 2045. The data now makes it hard to disagree.

This isnâ€™t science fiction anymore. Itâ€™s the trajectory weâ€™re on.

Over the next few weeks, we are launching some new compute-intensive offerings. Because of the associated costs, some features will initially only be available to Pro subscribers, and some new products will have additional fees.

Our intention remains to drive the cost of intelligence down as aggressively as we can and make our services widely available, and we are confident we will get there over time.

But we also want to learn what's possible when we throw a lot of compute, at today's model costs, at interesting new ideas.

Last week, our reasoning models took part in the 2025 International Collegiate Programming Contest (ICPC), the worldâ€™s premier university-level programming competition. Our system solved all 12 out of 12 problems, a performance that would have placed first in the world (the best human team solved 11 problems).

This milestone rounds off an intense 2 months of competition performances by our models:
- A second place finish in AtCoder Heuristics World Finals
- Gold medal at the International Mathematical Olympiad
- Gold medal at the International Olympiad in Informatics
- And now, a gold medal, first place finish at the ICPC World Finals.

I believe these results, coming from a family of general reasoning models rooted in our main research program, are perhaps the clearest benchmark of progress this year. These competitions are great self-contained, time-boxed tests for the ability to discover new ideas. Even before our models were proficient at simple arithmetic, we looked towards these contests as milestones of progress towards transformative artificial intelligence.

Our models now rank among the top humans in these domains, when posed with well-specified questions and restricted to ~5 hours. The challenge now is moving to more open-ended problems, and much longer time horizons. This level of reasoning ability, applied over months and years to problems that really matter, is what weâ€™re after - automating scientific discovery.

This rapid progress also underscores the importance of safety & alignment research. We still need more understanding of the alignment properties of long-running reasoning models; in particular, I recommend reviewing the fascinating findings from the study of scheming in reasoning models that we released today (
https://
x.com/OpenAI/status/
1968361701784568200
â€¦)!

Congratulations to my teammates that poured their hearts into getting these competition results, and to everyone contributing to the underlying fundamental research that enables them!

The humanoid robot curve is insane.

 In 2025: cost ~$35,000 each, just ~18,000 units shipped.
 By 2030â€“35: cost falls to $13â€“17k, shipments explode past 1 million per year.
 By 2060: nearly 3 billion robots in use worldwide.

Thatâ€™s smartphones-level adoption, except these wonâ€™t just scroll, theyâ€™ll work.

The question isnâ€™t if humanoid robots arriveâ€¦ itâ€™s who can afford not to use one.

bookmarks.text:
This chart from Bank of America isnâ€™t just about robots, itâ€™s about the end of labor as we know it.

 By the 2050s, weâ€™re looking at billions of humanoid robots in homes, services, and industry.
 Hardware costs will fall from ~$35k today to ~$15k or less, making them as common as cars or smartphones.

When machines can perform nearly every repetitive, dangerous, or boring task and they scale by the billions, our economy flips:

â€¢Labor shortages disappear.
â€¢Productivity becomes essentially infinite.
â€¢Goods and services trend toward abundance with near-zero marginal cost.

This is the roadmap to a post-labor, post-scarcity society.

Not â€œsomeday science fiction.â€ The data says by mid-century.

Iâ€™m really excited to share that our 
@OpenAI
 reasoning system got a perfect score of 12/12 during the 2025 ICPC World Finals, the premier collegiate programming competition where top university teams from around the world solve complex algorithmic problems. This would have placed it first among all human participants.

top_replies.author: MostafaRohani
top_replies.text:
2/n
We officially competed in the onsite AI track of the ICPC, with the same 5-hour time limit to solve all twelve problems, submitting to the ICPC World Finals Local Judge - judged identically and concurrently to the ICPC World Championship submissions. We received the problems

top_replies.author: MostafaRohani
top_replies.text:
3/n
We competed with an ensemble of general-purpose reasoning models; we did not train any model specifically for the ICPC. We had both GPT-5 and an experimental reasoning model generating solutions, and the experimental reasoning model selecting which solutions to submit. GPT-5

top_replies.author: MostafaRohani
top_replies.text:
4/n
This result is a great capstone to our streak of results showcasing the impressive pace of improvement of our reasoning systems. The same set of models also competed in the IMO and IOI, highlighting the generality of these systems.

top_replies.author: MostafaRohani
top_replies.text:
5/n
This is just the beginning, and Iâ€™m personally very excited about our research roadmap. The next frontier is the discovery of new knowledge, which is the true milestone at the end of the day.

We shipped something big: 

AI that scrapes every career site on the internet, and applies to matching jobs for you.

No job boards, no templates. Literally 100s of tailored applications sent out while you get on with your life.

top_replies.author: aidancramer
top_replies.text:
Because letâ€™s be real: applying to jobs is broken.
Itâ€™s just copy-pasting the same CV into 50 forms until you lose the will to live.

top_replies.author: aidancramer
top_replies.text:
So we asked: what if AI could do the boring part?
Scan roles. Match you. Auto-fill everything.
And do it in minutes.

top_replies.author: aidancramer
top_replies.text:
Instead of sending 10 apps in an evening, you wake up with 100 already sent.
Your input = career goals + CV.
The rest = autopilot.

top_replies.author: aidancramer
top_replies.text:
This isnâ€™t about spamming jobs.
Itâ€™s about removing the bottleneck between talent and opportunity.
The part humans hate â†’ let AI handle it.

top_replies.author: aidancramer
top_replies.text:
We call it AIApply Auto-Apply.
Itâ€™s the job hunt flipped upside down.
AI hunts for you, not the other way round.

Imagine this: Itâ€™s 2065.

Nobody works for survival anymore, AI and automation run the entire economy. Food, shelter, knowledge, and energy are abundant, cheaper than todayâ€™s tap water. Scarcity is a word in history books.

Humans donâ€™t retire, they reinvent. At 80, you look 40, because longevity escape velocity was hit in the 2040s. Life spans are open-ended; â€œdeath by agingâ€ is seen as a primitive tragedy, like dying of smallpox.

Children grow up in a world where money is a cultural relic, not a necessity. Instead of labor, people pursue curiosity, creation, and meaning. You donâ€™t earn a living, you live, and choose how to shape your existence.

The thought experiment: if a society without scarcity, aging, or labor truly emergesâ€¦ what will humans do with eternity? Will we flourish in infinite exploration, or struggle to find purpose when survival is no longer the game?

The future isnâ€™t about what we can build, but whether weâ€™re ready for what happens when every constraint weâ€™ve ever known dissolves.

Would you thrive or lose yourself, in such a world?

This may be the biggest AI/health breakthrough of the year 

New AI can cook up cures for cancer and heals at the cellular level.

Harvard scientists just developed a potential game changer for medicine: PDGrapher, a free AI model that doesnâ€™t just find drug targets, it figures out treatments that reverse disease states in cells.

"The tool identifies the best single or combined targets for treatments that correct the disease process."

Instead of the old trial and error method of testing one protein at a time, PDGrapher uses graph neural networks to map the entire cellular network, pinpoint the key drivers of disease, and suggest the best single or combo treatments to restore health.

Tested on 19 datasets across 11 cancers, it rediscovered known drug targets, uncovered new ones like KDR and TOP2A, and outperformed other AI tools with up to 35% better accuracy and 25Ã— faster results.

What it means:

faster drug discovery, 
smarter personalized medicine,  
breakthroughs for hard to treat diseases like cancer, Parkinsonâ€™s, and Alzheimerâ€™s. From just one AI tool.

SAM ALTMAN: "Elon Musk helped us start OpenAI, I'm very grateful for that. I really, for a long time, looked up to him as just an incredible hero, a great jewel of humanity. Anyway, he helped us start OpenAI, and he later decided that we weren't on a trajectory to be successful, he kind of told us we had a 0% chance of success. And then we did okay. bookmarks.author_name: Brandon K. Hill | CEO of btraxx/2

bookmarks.text:
New in Gemini Canvas: Select and Ask

You can now visually edit any part of your web app just by clicking an element and describing the change. No code necessaryâ€”just click, describe, and see your updates instantly in preview mode.

images.alt: An image showing Gemini's "Select and Ask" feature in action within Gemini Canvas. A user is visually editing a task and calendar app prototype by clicking an element (September 12th on the calendar) and describing a change "Make this green".

top_replies.author: GeminiApp
top_replies.text:
Learn more about Gemini Canvas: 
http://
gemini.google/overview/canvas

top_replies.author: Blazerdan142102
top_replies.text: Fix the raw math latex in android...

top_replies.author: GeminiApp
top_replies.text: Hi there, we understand it's frustrating when a core feature like math rendering isn't working as it should. Please ensure your Gemini app is updated, and if the issue persists, send us feedback from your device so our team can look into it. Thanks!

top_replies.author: Hunter_Lott_
top_replies.text:
The Code/Preview buttons consistently disappear from my Canvas window for no apparent reason.

Iâ€™ve tried asking Gemini to fix it, Iâ€™ve tried reloading the page. I usually end up having to just start an entirely new chat which is not very time efficient. 

Any recommendations?

top_replies.author: GeminiApp
top_replies.text: Hi there. That's not the experience we want you to have. We've made a note of your feedback and shared it with our Gemini team internally. Please stay tuned for future updates. Thank you for letting us know how we can improve!

top_replies.author: Trstmeimadogtor
top_replies.text: I'm trying to upload a logo png for my app web but it never shows up... Now I try to use this tool to select the problem but still doesn't work.. Can you please fix this?

top_replies.author: GeminiApp
top_replies.text: Hi there. We understand your concern, and thanks for sending this over. We're always working to improve your experience with Gemini, so we'll be sure to pass this along to the right people.

top_replies.author: verysmallwoods
top_replies.text: I don't see the feature in my Gemine app. Do I need to upgrade my plan?

top_replies.author: GeminiApp
top_replies.text: Hi there. Thanks for the interest. The "Select and Ask" feature for Gemini Canvas is currently a new, experimental feature. It is rolling out gradually to web users and may not be visible in the Gemini app on mobile devices yet. We appreciate your patience.

top_replies.author: VibeCodeTeddy
top_replies.text: This is cool, but what about mobile access? Sounds like a major gap for on-the-go users.

bookmarks.text:
Big AI/science news 

New amazing AI from Google can write expert level science software, and can do it 100x - 1000x faster than humans.

AI science acceleration

Researchers developed an AI system that can write expert level scientific software to speed up discoveries. 

It combines a large language model with tree search to explore ideas and improve results.

The AI created 40 new bioinformatics methods that beat human designed ones, 14 epidemiology models that outperformed the CDCâ€™s COVID-19 forecasts, and produced state of the art tools in areas like geospatial analysis, neuroscience, time series forecasting, and math.

And this is just the beginning.

bookmarks.text:
Microsoft is moving away from OpenAI for Office 365 and bringing Anthropic on board. 

Claude models will be used for certain Copilot features in Word, Excel, and PowerPoint in the futureâ€”especially where they perform better according to internal tests, such as in spreadsheet functions or more attractive presentations.

There are two sides to this: on the one hand, it improves product quality, and on the other, it sends a signal to OpenAI, with whom Microsoft is currently engaged in tough negotiations anyway. 

Another interesting point is that Microsoft has to pay for Anthropic via AWS, while OpenAI models are free for them under the existing partnership.

bookmarks.text:
OpenAI is partnering with an unnamed startup to produce Critterz, a feature-length animated film generated largely with its own AI tools. 

The team aims to premiere the movie at the 2026 Cannes Film Festival, showcasing how generative AI can slash both cost and production time compared with traditional Hollywood workflows. 

OpenAI will provide its compute resources and proprietary models to drive much of the animation and editing pipeline.

Roman Yampolskiy, a professor of computer science and pioneer in the field of AI safety, claimed in a podcast that by 2030, around 99% of all jobs could be automated by AI â€“ from software jobs to physical activities. He believes that AGI could become a reality as early as 2027 â€“ and then render almost all jobs obsolete within five years.

I don't find his theories convincing that we will ultimately end up at 99%. But more and more voices are joining in, and the first empirical data suggests that Dario Amodei is right and that we will see serious shifts in the entry-level sector and the first major impacts on the labor market due to AI.

I will conduct a major study in the coming weeks, compile all the data, and see what empirical research has to say on the matter.

top_replies.author: nyxia_ai
top_replies.text:
He literally said the unemployment rate will be 99%. In less than 4.5 years.

By all respect, optimism and appreciation of diverse sets of opinions.

This is just utterly pathetic attention grabbing bait.

top_replies.author: H8KUcom
top_replies.text: Give me a list of jobs you think AI and automation won't take over

top_replies.author: districtai
top_replies.text: is someone tracking all of these predictions?  I have a feeling almost all of these will prove to be untrue and the predictions will just be memory holed

top_replies.author: Hello_World
top_replies.text:
AI safety is a made up field literally invented in the Less Wrong forums along with terms like Alignment.

Don't listen to people who make utopian or dystopian predictions about the future they are just guessing.

top_replies.author: systemic_whisk
top_replies.text: It's a dumb claim that ignores societal inertia. That professor should spend some time with actual humans periodically, or I dunno, review previous adoption cycles.

top_replies.author: _junaidkhalid1
top_replies.text:
I'm skeptical of the 99% figure too, but the real story is in the entry-level impact. 

When AI starts automating junior roles, it creates a bottleneck for developing senior talent. 

The entire career pipeline breaks down, not just specific jobs.

top_replies.author: avanirajput1
top_replies.text: Ambitious claims make headlines, but the real story is in measured, empirical timelines and sector-by-sector impacts.

top_replies.author: SeanCloutier1
top_replies.text: I think AI is great...but this prediction is click-bait...people think replacing an assistant that handles clients, phone calls, emails, is easy...even this "low level" job requires abilities and skills AI is nowhere near achieving...around 2035 we will begin to see the lift

OpenAI plans to mass-produce its own AI chips starting in 2026â€”a move that could significantly reduce its dependence on Nvidia and other companies. 

Together with Broadcom, the company is developing a special series of processors (â€œXPUâ€) intended exclusively for its own use. 

The reason for this is the enormous computing power required by modern models such as GPT-5, which until now could only be met by extremely expensive GPU clusters.

It's coming. More and more reports about the coming unemployment are being published.

"The Gerald Huff Fund for Humanity today released Impact of AI on Workers in the United States,  a groundbreaking analysis revealing that artificial intelligence is on  track to disrupt roughly one in four U.S. jobs by 2028. The report warns  that we are entering an economic upheaval on a scale seen only once a  century, requiring bold policy responses to protect families and  communities."

- Job Disruption â€“ 45.3 million jobs are at risk of being disrupted by AI by 2028.

- Shift in Automation â€“ AI is advancing into white-collar,  cognitive, and administrative work, from HR and finance to customer  service, education, and healthcare, not just physical labor.

- Hardest-Hit Sectors â€“ Retail, Finance, Education, and Real Estate face the highest levels of expected disruptions.

- Skill Protection â€“ Human-centric skills such as empathy, adaptability, and judgment will be the strongest defense against automation.

- Retraining Limits â€“ Historical trends show that retraining alone often leads to lower wages and long-term income loss.

The US is massively expanding its energy production, but even there, prices are rising significantly because demand is driving supply.

China, on the other hand, is massively expanding solar energy.

Whoever solves the problem of electricity production will win the AI race.

Weâ€™re releasing new Codex features to make it a more effective coding collaborator:

- A new IDE extension
- Easily move tasks between the cloud and your local environment
- Code reviews in GitHub
- Revamped Codex CLI

Powered by GPT-5 and available through your ChatGPT plan.

top_replies.author: OpenAIDevs
top_replies.text:
Codex now runs in your IDE

Available for VS Code, Cursor, and other forks, the new extension makes it easy to share contextâ€”files, snippets, and diffsâ€”so you can work faster with Codex.

Itâ€™s been a top feature request, and weâ€™re excited to hear what you think!

top_replies.author: OpenAIDevs
top_replies.text:
Hand off to the cloud from your IDE.

Kick off new tasks, delegate in-progress work, and review results without leaving your editor.

Then continue tasks from Codex web in your IDE to keep building locally, without losing context.

top_replies.author: OpenAIDevs
top_replies.text:
Code reviews

Codex goes beyond static analysisâ€”it checks a PR against its intent, reasons across the codebase and dependencies, and can run code to validate the behavior of changes.

Set it up to auto-review new PRs in your repo, or tag @ codex.

top_replies.author: OpenAIDevs
top_replies.text:
Codex CLI

Weâ€™ve rebuilt the Codex CLI to harness GPT-5â€™s agentic coding capabilities so it's more reliable and capable.

Weâ€™ve redesigned the terminal UI and also added image inputs, message queuing, simplified approval modes, to-do lists, web search, and more.

top_replies.author: OpenAIDevs
top_replies.text:
With these updates, Codex works as one agent across your IDE, terminal, cloud, GitHub, and even on your phone â€” all connected by your ChatGPT account. 

Itâ€™s all included in Plus, Pro, Team, Edu, and Enterprise plans. Check out the new Codex developer hub to get started.

top_replies.text: If AGI changes what we call money, it wonâ€™t erase value - it may free us to see it in new forms. Connection, creativity, care - these might become the currencies that matter most.
