David Scott Patterson
@davidpattersonx
ç¿»è¨³ã‚’è¡¨ç¤º
I predict AGI and ASI will be achieved by the end of 2026.

Since these terms lack precise definitions, I define Artificial General Intelligence as the point when AI begins replacing all human workers - the human-to-AI transition point.

Artificial Super Intelligence can be defined as the point when AI matches the intelligence of the smartest humans, and becomes capable of innovation.

People tend to develop unique insights and innovative ideas above an IQ of 130.

By early 2026, AI will reach an IQ of 130, equal to the top 2% of humans.

By the end of 2026, it will reach an IQ of 150, the level of the top 0.04% of humans.

We are already seeing signs of insight from AI at an IQ of 123. This will improve rapidly over the next year.

Significant job disruption and AI-driven innovation could emerge within a year.

I define Artificial Universal Intelligence (AUI) as AIâ€™s ultimate limit of knowledge (kMAX) and intelligence (gMAX), which I project will be reached by 2029.

However, AIâ€™s practical impact will arrive much earlier, since it does not need to reach gMAX to replace human jobs or begin solving major problems.

AI data centers will require massive power increases - from 4 GW in 2024 to an estimated 123 GW by 2035 (30x growth).

-This corresponds to roughly all households in Germany, France, and Spain combined

Some future data center campuses could consume 5 GW - enough to power 5 million homes.

The Insanity of AI - The World in the Near Future

Hard to take economists and analysts predictions about the future of any country seriously when they just look at today's TFR (fertility rate) and completely ignore the AI revolution.

Agents capable of doing (autonomously) equivalent of billions of hours worth of human work will be here around 2030 (currently it's just ~2hours), yet economists worry about low TFR, an issue that will only be felt 25 years from now.

TFR wonâ€™t matter. AI will completely change and revolutionize everything, and it will happen in just a few years. Solve fusion, solve aging, solve scarcity, reinvent current economic system, reinvent everything.

No one knows exactly what it will look like,  the numbers are too insane. If an entire country used this tech, it would be like increasing its population by a factor of a billion/s.

Imagine the acceleration of everything if the US population wasnâ€™t 340 million but 340 quadrillion.

This is just an increase by 1 billion, but I don't see any reason why it wouldn't be an increase by 10,50 or 300 billion. But let's stay with 1 billion.

Iâ€™m aware that not everyone is working, and not everyone is doing cognitive work. But to reach that equivalent, youâ€™d only need to increase the cognitive workforce by the low billions, instead of entire population by 1 billion, still the low billion range. In the U.S. case, that would be ~85 million Ã— 4 billion.

Even a small country like Estonia, with ~1 million people, would have an output (cognitive work) comparable to 1 quadrillion people(or more), equivalent to 125,000 Earth populations 

I tried to keep it simple. Iâ€™m not even taking into account that in some cases these AI agents will be doing those billions worth of human work hours in minutes, working 24/7/365, and collaborating with billions of other AIs.

Pure insanity

Another insane AI news

AI just identified 12,623 potential new antibiotics

A recent University of Pennsylvania study harnessed AI called APEX to probe the biology of archaeal organisms. 

By analyzing the proteomes of 233 different archaeal species, the team uncovered 12,623 molecules that may possess antimicrobial properties.

Named archaeasins, these compounds seem to target bacteria in an unusual way, rather than damaging the outer defenses, they disrupt the cellâ€™s internal electrical signals, effectively shutting it down from within.

top_replies.author: jasonzhou1993
top_replies.text:
First -

Why did Anthropic build sub-agents initially?

It's all about context engineer & context optimisations

It works best when focusing on planning & researching and send back with a summary plan to conversation thread

top_replies.author: jasonzhou1993
top_replies.text:
However, 

Context sharing between sub-agents is non-exist

That's why if you have sub-agent do actual work, then this context is not visible to all other agents

This cause problems...

top_replies.author: jasonzhou1993
top_replies.text:
Meanwhile,

@ManusAI_HQ has this blog on how they use file storage as the ultimate context system

It inspired me to design a context sharing setup to get main agent & sub agents to share context between each other

Hi Jeff, I agree that it's not representative, I said this in the thread.

Re: cherrypicked tasks, we've found that our result (exponential increase in task length) is pretty robust across various collections of taskshttps://metr.org/blog/2025-07-14-how-does-time-horizon-vary-across-domains/â€¦Your point about different logistics

top_replies.author: preshing
top_replies.text:
You're the fourth AI safety person to appear in my feed with that graph since GPT-5 came out. Sorry, but it isn't the smoking gun you think it is.

 The underlying study is based on a cherry-picked collection of ~200 specific tasks, some of which take humans less than a minute

top_replies.author: nikolaj2030
top_replies.text:
Hi Jeff, I agree that it's not representative, I said this in the thread.

Re: cherrypicked tasks, we've found that our result (exponential increase in task length) is pretty robust across various collections of tasks 
https://
metr.org/blog/2025-07-1
4-how-does-time-horizon-vary-across-domains/
â€¦

Your point about different logistics is correct! I think that summarizing the result into a single metric is tricky and wonder if you have takes for better ways of representing the length of tasks agents can do over time?

top_replies.author: preshing
top_replies.text: That paper presents similar "time horizon" graphs for non-programming benchmarks. If you really want to understand how coding agents are evolving, don't just fixate on the lengths of benchmark tasks AI can do (especially in unrelated domains). Look instead at the differences

top_replies.author: nikolaj2030
top_replies.text:
I agree, as time goes on we need more realistic benchmarks to make meaningful claims about AI progress. 

In our original paper we did a bit of exploration into performance on "messy" tasks in our set but we definitely need more of this type of work: 
https://
arxiv.org/pdf/2503.14499

bookmarks.text:
Has AI progress slowed down? Iâ€™ll write some personal takes and predictions in this thread.

The main metric I look at is METRâ€™s time horizon, which measures the length of tasks agents can perform. It has been doubling for more than 6 years now, and might have sped up recently.

top_replies.author: nikolaj2030
top_replies.text:
By measuring the length of tasks AI agents can complete, we can get a continuous metric of AI capabilities.

Since 2019, the time horizon has been doubling every 7 months. But since 2024, itâ€™s been doubling every 4 months. What if we irresponsibly extrapolated these to 2030?

top_replies.author: nikolaj2030
top_replies.text: If AI progress continues at its recent rate, we get AI systems which can do one month (167 hours) of low-context SWE work by the end of 2027. If AI progress continues at the long-run historical rate, we get them by the end of 2029 instead.

top_replies.author: nikolaj2030
top_replies.text: How to interpret one work-month? Iâ€™d say itâ€™s something like the first project a new hire would do, or the type of work a researcher who just switched teams would be able to do in a month. Our time horizon metric currently doesnâ€™t define high time horizons super sharply.

top_replies.author: nikolaj2030
top_replies.text: Changing the success rate threshold from 50% to 80% only shifts the extrapolation from recent progress by a few months, but shifts the extrapolation from the long-run historical rate by around a year.

top_replies.author: nikolaj2030
top_replies.text: I donâ€™t think these lines should be extrapolated much past one work-month, as progress will likely speed up even more once AIs are automating significant parts of AI research. Additionally, bottlenecks identified by Epoch AI might slow down compute scaling around 2030.

top_replies.author: nikolaj2030
top_replies.text: Our task suite is currently composed of well-scoped easily-scoreable tasks, which makes them pretty different from the type of work done in the real world. This means that we should be cautious when interpreting these extrapolations.

GPT-5 isnâ€™t just getting smarter, itâ€™s getting self-aware.

OpenAIâ€™s secret weapon isnâ€™t just more data or parameters. Itâ€™s something deeper: Universal Verifiers.

These are specialized AI models trained to fact-check, evaluate, and grade the output of other models using real-world sources, not unlike a professor reviewing a thesis. Every logical step, every assumption, every hallucinated â€œfactâ€ gets scrutinized.

This isnâ€™t just quality control. Itâ€™s a paradigm shift.

Why? Because it means:
â€¢Models can now teach each other.
â€¢Reasoning chains become auditable.
â€¢Truthfulness becomes programmable.
â€¢Subjective domains like ethics, creativity, and decision-making can be tackled with reliable scaffolding.

GPT-5 is no longer just generating text, itâ€™s learning how to verify its own thoughts.

The age of self-refining intelligence has begun.

bookmarks.text:
The Information about GPT-4.5/5 and more: the tl;dr

GPT-4.5 (â€œOrionâ€)
Originally developed as Orion and planned as GPT-5.
Performance disappointing: no major leaps forward compared to GPT-4o.
Reasons for failure:
Dwindling supply of high-quality web data for pretraining.
Optimizations worked in small models but did not scale.
Consequence: Released as GPT-4.5 in February 2025 â€“ quickly lost significance.

GPT-5
Focus: Practical improvements instead of quantum leaps.
Coding & math: Writes cleaner, more feature-rich, and more user-friendly code.
Agent capabilities: Better at handling complex task lists and edge cases (e.g., refunds in support).
Efficiency: Uses computing resources more efficiently, delivers high-quality answers without massive increases in compute.

New technology:
Reinforcement learning with â€œUniversal Verifier,â€ which automatically checks answers.
Based on experience from the o series (o1, o3), which was strong for pure reasoning tasks but lost performance when chatting.
Result: Incremental but commercially valuable improvement â€“ not a leap like GPT-3 â†’ GPT-4.

Problems and internal dynamics
Technical hurdles:
Performance drop in chat models (â€œstudent modelsâ€).
Pretraining limits and data scarcity.

Internal tensions:
Researchers leaving for Meta (lock-in offers).
Conflicts between research and business: Resistance to too close a tie to Microsoft.
Visible friction between Mark Chen (head of research) and VP Jerry Tworek on Slack; Mark Chen at the same time, a controversial figure in team restructuring and researcher departures.

Microsoft deal:
Exclusive rights until 2030, planned ~33% stake in the for-profit structure.
Strategic negotiations are underway, while OpenAI is preparing for a possible IPO.

bookmarks.text:
Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei just gave THE MOST accelerated talk on how scaling will continue to make models exponentially more powerful for a long time to come â€” and that there is "NO WALL." 

- From 'Alex Kantrowitz' YT Channel (Full Video link in comment)

---

"The thing I think is real that I've said over and over again is the exponential. The idea that every few months we get an AI model that is better than the AI model we got before. And we get that by investing more compute in AI models, more data, more new types of training models.

Initially, this was done by what's called pre-training, which is when you just feed a bunch of data from the internet into the model. Now we have a second stage that's reinforcement learning or test time compute or reasoning or whatever you want to call it. I think of it as a second stage that involves reinforcement learning. Now both of those things are scaling up together, as we've seen with our models and as we've seen with models from other companies. I don't see anything blocking the further scaling of that.

There's some stuff about how do we broaden the tasks on the RL side of it. We've seen more progress on, say, math and code, where the models are getting pretty close to a high professional level, and less on more subjective tasks, but I think that is very much a temporary obstacle.

So when I look at it, I see this exponential and I say, look, people aren't very good at making sense of exponentials, right? Like, if something is doubling every 6 months, then 2 years before it happens, it looks like it's only 1/16th of the way there. And so we are sitting here in the middle of 2025, and the models are really starting to explode in terms of the economy.

If you look at the capabilities of the model, they're starting to saturate all the benchmarks. If you look at revenue, and you know, Anthropic's revenue every year has grown 10x. Every year weâ€™re kind of conservative and we say, it canâ€™t grow 10x this time. I never assume anything and actually always am very conservative in saying I think it's going to slow down on the business side. But we went from zero to $100 million in 2023, we went from $100 million to $1 billion in 2024, and this year, in the first half of the year, we've gone from $1 billion to, I think as of speaking today, it's well above $4 billion, it might be $4.5 billion.

And so if you think about it, suppose that exponential continued for 2 years. I'm not saying it will, but suppose it continued for 2 years. You're well into the $100 billions. I'm not saying that'll happen. I'm saying the situation is that when you're on an exponential, you can really get fooled by it. 2 years away from when the exponential goes totally crazy, it looks like it's just starting to be a thing.

And so that's the fundamental dynamic. We saw that with the internet in the '90s, right? Where it was like networking speeds and the underlying speed of the computers were getting fast, and over a few years it became possible to have to basically build a digital global communications network on top of all this when it wasn't possible just a few years ago and and almost no one except for a few people really saw the implications of that and how fast it."

- Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei

bookmarks.text:
SAM ALTMAN BELIEVES AGI IS SOLVED

â€œSo now we're starting to look ahead to superintelligence.â€

-
â€œWhen we started OpenAI, almost nine years ago now, we believed that AI could become the most impactful technology in human history. We didn't know exactly how we were going to get there, but we believed it was possible and that if we succeeded, we wanted to make sure that it benefited everyone. 

At the time, very few people believed in AGI. We kept learning by doing. We had some breakthroughs. We had some setbacks. We got lucky in some places. We got unlucky in some places. And in the way that technology moves forward, we now are in a place where everyone can see this tremendous impact that AI is going to have in the future. 

So now we're starting to look ahead to superintelligence. 

And even more than before, our focus must be on wide and fair access. This is a technology that will reshape the global economy and really the whole way we live our lives. It's critical that superintelligence becomes cheap, broadly available, and not that concentrated with any one person, company, or country. 

We, not just OpenAI, but the whole industry, we are building something PROFOUND. This is a kind of BRAIN OF THE WORLD. It'll be personal, adaptable, it'll be easy to use, it'll give people incredible superpowers that were sort of science fiction only a couple of years ago. 

The limit won't be the algorithms and the research, but it'll increasingly become the physical instantiation that it takes to make this work. Chips, cables, servers, energy, everything that you need to power this brain. And the more of it, the better. 

I think that Norway offers more of that potential right here in Europe. It will contribute to the overall compute power needed to drive the next wave of AI breakthroughs and deployment and economic progress for Europe and Europe. I'm incredibly excited about what this will create for the future. 
Thank you.â€

MASSIVE claim in this paper. 

AI Architectural breakthroughs can be scaled computationally, transforming research progress from a human-limited to a computation-scalable process. 

So it turns architecture discovery into a computeâ€‘bound process, opening a path to selfâ€‘accelerating model evolution without waiting for human intuition.

The paper shows that an allâ€‘AI research loop can invent novel model architectures faster than humans, and the authors prove it by uncovering 106 recordâ€‘setting linearâ€‘attention designs that outshine human baselines.

Right now, most architecture search tools only fineâ€‘tune blocks that people already proposed, so progress crawls at the pace of human trialâ€‘andâ€‘error.

 Why we needed a fresh approach

Human researchers tire quickly, and their search space is narrow. As model families multiply, deciding which tweak matters becomes guesswork, so whole research agendas stall while hardware idles.

 Meet ASIâ€‘ARCH, the selfâ€‘driving lab

The team wired together three LLMâ€‘based roles. A â€œResearcherâ€ dreams up code, an â€œEngineerâ€ trains and debugs it, and an â€œAnalystâ€ mines the results for patterns, feeding insights back to the next round. A memory store keeps every motivation, code diff, and metric so the agents never repeat themselves.

 Across 1,773 experiments and 20,000 GPU hours, a straight line emerged between compute spent and new SOTA hits. 

Add hardware, and the system keeps finding winners without extra coffee or conferences.

>>> Qwen3-Coder is here! 

Weâ€™re releasing Qwen3-Coder-480B-A35B-Instruct, our most powerful open agentic code model to date. This 480B-parameter Mixture-of-Experts model (35B active) natively supports 256K context and scales to 1M context with extrapolation. It achieves top-tier performance across multiple agentic coding benchmarks among open models, including SWE-bench-Verified!!! 

Alongside the model, we're also open-sourcing a command-line tool for agentic coding: Qwen Code. Forked from Gemini Code, it includes custom prompts and function call protocols to fully unlock Qwen3-Coderâ€™s capabilities. Qwen3-Coder works seamlessly with the communityâ€™s best developer tools. As a foundation model, we hope it can be used anywhere across the digital world â€” Agentic Coding in the World!

bookmarks.text:
OpenAI has achieved gold-level at the International Math Olympiad

(People used to say they'd consider this AGI, btw.)

Why this matters:

50% chance of fast takeoff? Paul Christiano - inventor of RLHF, certified genius, and arguably the most respected alignment researcher in the world - previously said he'd update from 30% to 50% chance of a hard takeoff if we saw an IMO gold by 2025.

In 2021 Paul thought there was only an 8% chance of this happening! Eliezer said "at least 16%"

Paul was famously the most well-known slow-takeoff advocate (slow takoff meaning, like, AGI unfolds over years to decades) vs foom/fast/hard takeoff (minutes to months)

Fast takeoffs are scary because they're way less predictable. Human institutions have almost no time to adapt to insane rates of change.

Historically, perhaps ~30% of AI safety researchers thought a fast takeoff is more likely than slow takeoff

top_replies.author: ZincDoge
top_replies.text: I'm still a bit fuzzy on the whole 'fast takeoff' definition. At the AGI threshold running at Ghz speeds it's already millions of years of progress every year. So how will it not be 'fast'? What's their standard? Until the thing is able to perform magic, violating known physics?

Eric Schmidt on Moonshots with Peter Diamandis.

Eric Schmidt says traditional user interfaces are going to go away.

The WIMP model (windows, icons, menus, pull-downs) was built 50 years ago.

In the age of agents, UI becomes ephemeral. Generated on demand, shaped by intent, not layout.

2027 â€” The Automation of Physical Reality

bookmarks.text:
ğ—”ğ—œ ğ—”ğ—´ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ ğ— ğ—²ğ—ºğ—¼ğ—¿ğ˜† explained in a simple way 

In general, the memory for an agent is something that we provide via context in the prompt passed to LLM that helps the agent to better plan and react given past interactions or data not immediately available.

It is useful to group the memory into four types:

ğŸ­. Episodic - This type of memory contains past interactions and actions performed by the agent. After an action is taken, the application controlling the agent would store the action in some kind of persistent storage so that it can be retrieved later if needed. A good example would be using a vector Database to store semantic meaning of the interactions.
ğŸ®. Semantic - Any external information that is available to the agent and any knowledge the agent should have about itself. You can think of this as a context similar to one used in RAG applications. It can be internal knowledge only available to the agent or a grounding context to isolate part of the internet scale data for more accurate answers.
ğŸ¯. Procedural - This is systemic information like the structure of the System Prompt, available tools, guardrails etc. It will usually be stored in Git, Prompt and Tool Registries.
ğŸ°. Occasionally, the agent application would pull information from long-term memory and store it locally if it is needed for the task at hand.
ğŸ±. All of the information pulled together from the long-term or stored in local memory is called short-term or working memory. Compiling all of it into a prompt will produce the prompt to be passed to the LLM and it will provide further actions to be taken by the system.

We usually label 1. - 3. as Long-Term memory and 5. as Short-Term memory.

A visual explanation of potential implementation details 

And that is it! The rest is all about how you architect the topology of your Agentic Systems. 

What are your thoughts about memory in AI Agents?

#LLM #AI #MachineLearning

Hooks are user-defined shell commands that execute at various points in Claude Codeâ€™s agent loop.

They give you deterministic control over Claude Codeâ€™s behavior to ensure certain actions always happen at certain times.

- Notifications (e.g. via Slack) on prompt completions
- Logging and observability
- Custom permissions and approvals
- Running lints after every write

top_replies.author: alexalbert__
top_replies.text: To create a hook, run the /hooks command within Claude Code. Select the kind of hook event (when you want the action triggered), then define the hook command.

top_replies.author: alexalbert__
top_replies.text:
For complex hooks, we recommend writing a script and calling it.

You can find an example in our repo here:

top_replies.author: alexalbert__
top_replies.text: Read the docs to get started with hooks and further customize Claude Code:

Sam Altman says the future of AI isn't request-and-response -- it's continuous and proactive

Imagine a world where personal AI agents constantly monitor Slack, email, and daily interactions, actively noticing needs

A team of agents, assistants, companions...doing stuff in the background all the time

top_replies.author: SledgeDev
top_replies.text: He says a lot of things

top_replies.author: rryssf_
top_replies.text: continuous monitoring sounds more intrusive than helpful. we need to tread carefully on privacy here. also, all this proactive stuff may just be glamorized automation. letâ€™s see it in action before we get too excited.

top_replies.author: FanTV_official
top_replies.text:
This vision changes how we think about workflows entirely. 

When agents donâ€™t wait for prompts, they become more like intuition than software.

top_replies.author: codewithimanshu
top_replies.text: Perhaps our own agency is the future of AI's future.

top_replies.author: prashan_agarwal
top_replies.text:
The shift from AI as a tool to AI as a teammate is closer than people think. 

Most people think the benefit is speed. 
But imagine if things are handled quietly before you even notice the need?

top_replies.author: nifty0x
top_replies.text: That would be nice. But what about the privacy aspect? Constant monitoring doesnâ€™t sound like a good idea

top_replies.author: LarryPanozzo
top_replies.text: I think he has always been right about this

top_replies.author: AllAboutAicom
top_replies.text:
But it also raises big questions:
How do we maintain control?
What gets delegated?
And how do we build trust in agents that act before we ask?

top_replies.author: m13v_
top_replies.text: This is exactly why we built Screenpipe to continuously capture everything happening on your screen so AI agents have the context they need to be truly proactive instead of reactive.

top_replies.author: overlordFelix
top_replies.text:
Prediction(Fact):
Agents will run the world

bookmarks.text:
Ilya Sutskever says AI could cure disease, extend life, and accelerate science beyond imagination.

But if it can do that, what else can it do?

â€œThe problem with AI is that it is so powerful. It can also do everything.â€

We don't know what's coming. We must prepare, together.
